list-item.p: How do UK overseas territories experience and create different biological security threats to the UK?
How might different understandings of the term ‘biological security’ be problematic for coordinated action across the UK government and for effective engagement with expert communities?
What have been the barriers to success of the different UK biological security regimes (e.g. wild and domestic animal health, plant health, aquatic health, bee health, invasive non-native species)?
Which components of the food system in the UK are most vulnerable to biological security risks?
What infrastructure (e.g. transport, health, and power) is most vulnerable to biological security threats?
What are the key challenges and opportunities that Brexit poses for UK biological security, and how can these best be responded to?
What are the most significant re-emergent biological security threats and do our current threat characteristics accommodate them?

What could be done to accelerate investment and development of novel, agile, low-cost systems that could be used for distribution and responsive manufacturing of therapies to combat infectious human, animal and plant disease outbreaks?
How can we best build capacity in Parliament to help implement the UK Biological Security Strategy?
How effective are mechanisms to support cross-government coordination necessary for implementation of the UK Biological Security Strategy?
How effective are the methods being used to monitor the implementation of the UK Biological Security Strategy?
How can natural capital valuation help prioritize biological security efforts?

How can new biological, computational and hardware technologies be used to balance border controls and trade in living materials such as seeds, plants, livestock and wild animals, while reducing the risk of pathogen transmission?
How can we measure the success and failure of biological security interventions in the UK and adaptively use this to improve our responses?
What mechanisms exist for recognizing and dealing with the unknowns in biological security?
How do we design measures to improve biological security that do not unnecessarily restrict scientists from conducting fundamental and applied research?
